Description: Rim sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery heavy chalice; creamy slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; rosette and palmette in added red and white; exterior: 'Z' band between dilute bands at rim; below, painted decoration consisting of part of charioteer holding reins (head and lower body missing) to right; pendant tongue, short vertical strokes and rosette as filling ornament; three ancient repair holes on left break and part of one on right break.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The thickness of the sherd and the diameter suggest that the vase was a heavy chalice. Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to The Group with the Filling Ornament. The features typical for this group of vessels are the milky white slip and the use of filling ornament, which is found only in this group of sherds of the Grand Style. The presence of filling ornament also suggests that the vases were mostly likely the earliest in that style. The male figures portrayed on vases from this group are perhaps the most expertly depicted and may all have been done by the same hand. Finally, the attempt at creating some perspective is rather clumsy.
